Award.AwardTitle: Bottom-up synthesis of filamentous polymer nanoparticles through bio-templated approaches
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Jon Pokorski and Nicole Steinmetz of Case Western Reserve University will develop methods to form complex polymeric nanostructures based on the templated polymer growth from a biological scaffold, specifically tobacco mosaic virus (TMV). The bottom-up synthesis of polymeric nanoparticles with controlled sizes and features, such as ligand spacing is a critical need in nanoscience. The approach involves exploring three methods to synthesize rod-shaped nanostructures: 1) using ATRP to graft polymers from the exterior of TMV, 2) grafting polymers from the interior surface of TMV, followed by removal of the template to yield high-aspect ratio polymeric nanoparticles, and 3) polymerize both on the interior and exterior surface to yield complex inside-out polymeric nanoparticles. The template surface can be modified using genetic engineering methods in order to increase or decrease the particle dimensions in a rational manner. Organizing functional molecules in deterministic arrays provides a means to chemically program new functional devices for applications in medicine and energy. The broader impacts of the project also involve training graduate and undergraduate students, as well as participation in the Polymer Envoy Program for training high school students in Cleveland's school districts.

The creation of precisely defined structures that have dimensions on the order of nanometers (termed "nanostructures") continues to be a challenge for chemists. Nature has perfected the assembly of proteins into a myriad of nanostructures, particularly in the case of viruses. This project will develop new and innovative ways to synthesize these materials in a highly pure form using viruses as a scaffold for further materials synthesis. These types of virus-templated nanomaterials could find applications as promising platforms for drug delivery or as connecting elements in nanoelectronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins are critical components for a wide range of biotechnology applications spanning pharmaceutical sciences, ‘green’ energy, mitigation of toxic chemicals, disease sensing and as catalysts to form consumer products used daily. While proteins have evolved to perform a specific biological function, scientists have harnessed these molecules and repurposed them for the applications described above. A critical barrier to implementing proteins, however, is the need for proteins to remain stable in environments that the protein has not evolved to survive in. Potential scenarios where proteins may be inactivated are the human body, since the immune system recognizes these as foreign, catalysis at high temperatures, long-term device storage and the list goes on and on. The results of this project have contributed to elucidating novel ways to stabilize proteins. A common stabilization method is to attach a polymer, or an extremely large synthetic molecule, to the surface of proteins. Currently, there is a ‘gold-standard’ polymer known as PEG, that has remained a constant for ~40 years. This project used chemical synthesis to identify potential PEG replacements and fully characterized them both chemically and physically. One of the exciting outcomes of this project was the ability to identify a new polymer that better shielded proteins against the immune response. This is critical since PEG is such a common consumer additive. Because the population is exposed to PEG constantly, a significant proportion of people have generated an immune response against the polymer. This is especially problematic for pharmaceuticals with PEG attached. The polymer we discovered both better shields proteins from the immune system and is not the traditional PEG polymer, thus should avoid immune recognition of the polymer. The results of this work have great implications in the development of pharmaceutical proteins, as well as, contributing to protein stability in all protein-based applications. 

 


Last Modified: 09/11/2017
Modified by: Jonathan K Pokorski
